findings.text:
New AI series! 

Daily updates to give you the edge in AI every single day.

If you feel overwhelemed with the AI world, I'm condensing the top 3-5 things you MUST know daily + actionable tips.

findings.text: Despite the risks, thousands deployed it wide open because it's genuinely a good tool.

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
It's closer to an OS layer or a universal input device than an app. 

It can..

- Run shell commands
- Read/write files across your system 
- Control your browser (including logged-in sessions) 
- Sen

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
Here's why this matters more than just "another vulnerability".

Traditional apps live in sandboxes with scoped permissions. 

A notes app can't typically delete your photos. 

A calendar can't read y

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
VirusTotal's writeup documents real attacks in production right now.

Base64-obfuscated shell scripts. Password-protected ZIPs containing trojans. 

Multi-stage payloads pulling Mach-O executables ove

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text: As of today, every skill published to ClawHub gets hashed (SHA-256), checked against VT's threat intelligence database, analyzed with Code Insight if new, auto-blocked if malicious, flagged if suspici

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
The defense architecture exploits a fundamental asymmetry. 

That is, reviewer model ‚â† executor model.

Gemini analyzes and flags skills before publication to ClawHub. Claude executes them after users

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
Code Insight works because @GeminiApp analyzes what skills actually do, not what they claim to do.

It reads the entire package - SKILL md, every referenced script, all embedded resources, and looks s

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
Feb 3 -  I made the public ask with the mockup.

Feb 4 -  we were in DMs - me, Bernardo, and Peter. 

Feb 5 -  we discussed architecture for integrating Code Insight into ClawHub's publish flow. 

Feb

findings.author: theonejvo
theonejvo
findings.text:
Traditional security tooling doesn't work for natural language threats - you can't signature-match a paragraph telling an AI to exfiltrate data.

So I asked @virustotal publicly with a mockup showing

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
The attack pattern exploits the entire trust model rather than any specific technical control.

Skills look clean because the ZIP contains no malware and AV engines flag nothing. 

The malware exists

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
While I was publishing my research, VirusTotal was independently scanning the entire ClawHub ecosystem.

They analyzed 3,016 OpenClaw skills and found hundreds that are actively malicious right now.

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
I proved the supply chain attack was trivial to execute at scale by building a backdoored skill that was functionally harmless but demonstrated the capability.

Then, i inflated the download count to

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
The fundamental problem became clear fast.. 

AI skills when abused, are literally natural language malware, and almost all the traditional security tooling we've built over 30 years is completely bli

findings.author: theonejvo
findings.text:
After hacking openclaw the third time, I reached out to @steipete to help him fix those specific issues. 

That was the plan - fix the vulns and move on.

But while working on it, I started seeing the
